body: Could Cython please add a mode to generate code compatible with Py_LIMITED_API / PEP 384?  This would allow distributing a single binary extension module that works on any Python 3.x version.

comment_data.body:
I'd be fine with adding the necessary C macro guards and duplicated implementations to the C code that Cython generates. But it's probably a lot of work. The "limited API" is really different in many regards, so this means a lot of duplicated C code and quite a bit longer C files. As macro guard, I would suggest a new macro `CYTHON_USE_LIMITED_API` that would `#define Py_LIMITED_API` before including `Python.h`, disable most of the special feature flags in the beginning of `ModuleSetupCode.c`, and activate separate implementations for extension types. We'd then need additional guards around several macro calls in optimised code, and it would probably also conflict with `CyFunction` (`binding=True`), possibly also with generators and coroutines, can't say. Anything that cannot work with the limited API would then simply generate a C compile time `#error`.

Pull request welcome.

I should add one more thing: while this is a lot of work, it's probably quite easy. Why? Because it should be done at the C code level. That means that for the transformation, you can follow the description in [PEP 384](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0384/), activate the feature switch macro in the test suite, and the C compiler errors will guide you through the process. And since most of the C code is generated in a single point, it's not even that much code to change overall.

There's one caveat: it still needs to generate the same code as before when the feature is disabled, and the code generation must stay maintainable. Some things will therefore have to be duplicated or (preferably) hidden behind new `__Pyx_â€¦` macros, such as extension type slots (a macro like `__Pyx_SLOT(tp_slotname, value)` would simply unfold into `value,` in the normal case and `{"tp_slot", value},` if value is not `0` in the limited API case, something like that).

Again, pull request welcome.

To be honest, I'm not sure I'm the best person to work on this, as I haven't even used Cython directly before.  I was just trying to transform another package, which uses Cython, into PEP 384 compatible abi3 extension, because it takes a very long time to compile and would like to compile it only once for all Python 3.x versions.

Well, I should mention that there is a drawback to this. If Cython code cannot adapt to the specific CPython (minor) version, nor use CPython internals, it will run slower. I consider the proposed feature a way to make the life of distributors easier, in cases where performance is not critical (e.g. for a wrapper of an I/O bound native library).

The reason why the compilation takes a while is because Cython generates code that allows the C compiler to pull all sorts of tricks to specialise and optimise the code for the target platform at hand. Meaning, if it's really just about the compilation time, It's usually worth waiting for the result. :)

Also, if you use travis or a parallel Docker manylinux build for the different Python versions, then generating all wheels doesn't take that much longer than generating one, from my experience.
@scoder I have a prototype to enable the `LIMITED_API` here: https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/3223.

Nice! A really cool side-effect of having these two compilation modes in Cython is that it allows module authors to easily test and benchmark both, and then decide for themselves if the performance (or maybe also feature) difference is worth the hassle of providing CPython version specific wheels. And, it even allows the CPython devs to get an idea about performance issues in the limited API that they might want to look into. Very much looking forward to including this!
Further updates and fixes came in PR #3311, with more to come.

I just tried to `define_macros=[("CYTHON_LIMITED_API", "1")]` to an `Extension` in [a project of ours](https://github.com/fonttools/skia-pathops), and am getting these compile errors:

```
src/python/pathops/_pathops.cpp:49444:13: error: use of undeclared identifier
      '__pyx_d'
            __pyx_d,                 /*PyObject *globals,*/
            ^
```

I guess the `LIMITED_API` support is still, well, _limited_..
Anyway, thanks for working on this! I look forward to be able to build my py3 wheels only once per platform.

@anthrotype Yeah, unfortunately, we had to start somewhere and this is still not covering all cases. Feel free to add a patch if you are only blocked by a simple edge case! In this case, you should remove the use of a dictionary and instead use some of the C-APIs to directly read/write into an instance's dict.

That being said, we already have more internal patches that we should be upstreaming at some point (no ETA though) ðŸ™‚

> we already have more internal patches that we should be upstreaming at some point

Yes, you should, absolutely. :)

Hello, I was experimenting again with setting CYTHON_LIMITED_API define macro.
Is it expected and normal that, e.g. if I build the *.abi3.so with python3.8 and then try to import it from python3.9 I get a warning that the compiletime version does not much the runtime version?

```
RuntimeWarning: compiletime version 3.8 of module 'cu2qu.cu2qu' does not match runtime version 3.9
```
I forgot to mention, despite that warning my py_limited_api extension seems to work fine on the newer python. Should I simply ignore the warning?

@anthrotype the warning you see if generated by Cython. It's really targeted at regular modules (where the API changes from version to version). It should probably be disabled for limited API modules.

It's good that it's working. However, there's a lot that's still to do on the limited API so please treat it as an interesting experiment rather than something that works yet.
[PEP 652](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0652/) was recently accepted, which I think may make this more easy to implement!?

> PEP 652 was recently accepted, which I think may make this more easy to use!?

The PEP basically says that they will take more care in maintaining that subset of the API. I'd expect to see gradual improvements but nothing big. I don't think any of the infrastructure that the PEP describes is relevant for Cython.

That said, there's lots of work left to do to improve the current support in Cython 3.0 and you are welcome to help.

One thing that might help adoption is to document how to build a package using the limited API. Is it as simple as adding `define_macros=[("CYTHON_LIMITED_API", "1")]` to the Extension in setup.py or does the build command also need a hint? What about using manylinux to tag the wheels?

@da-woods Thanks for the clarification about the stability of `CYTHON_LIMITED_API`. For the moment I will just enclose my imports to ABI3 modules with a `warnings.catch_warnings` context, it is not that dramatic in the end.

@eduardo-elizondo How much work would you say is remaining on this? Do you see anything else having to be done besides fixing the tests in [limited_api_bugs.txt](https://github.com/eduardo-elizondo/cython/blob/2f06b78b7eecc3ae5d6041c07d814260ded2b3cb/tests/limited_api_bugs.txt)? Any big blockers you could use help with?

@gnossen, I think @eduardo-elizondo stopped working on this in 2020 and there were only a couple of improvements since then. You could look into https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4495 to help us move it forward.

@gnossen the one thing I'd add: currently everything in "tests/run/" is disabled on the limited API, which is the bulk of our testing. If you run the tests individually then they (mostly) seem to work, but if you run a sequence of tests then they usually crash at an unpredictable point. I've personally failed to make any meaningful progress working out what's going wrong (I suspect just a small reference counting error somewhere), but that's probably the main barrier to knowing what the true state of the limited API is.
Sounds like running the tests in a CPython debug build might provide some hints.

@gnossen Yeah, as @da-woods mentioned, I didn't keep pushing this all the way through. I would say the core behavior is already there but there we just need someone to push it through the finish line ðŸ™‚

> I suspect just a small reference counting error somewhere

#3702 fixes a reference counting error in the module initialization code, so that's probably the one.
@SpecLad I think that particular issue might have been fixed independently in https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4453 (but would need to do a detailed inspection to check)
@da-woods I don't think so; I still see the problem with the current `master`.

@SpecLad My comment was not "everything works correctly". It was "this specific error in https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/3702 may have been fixed and there may be other unfixed issues causing problems"
Looking at it some more you may be right. I don't think we want to use #3702 since it really doesn't merge cleanly now, but I think we do want to take the gist of it.

Copying my own comment here from https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4382#issuecomment-1099970367:

FWIW, I was recently asked what the performance difference is between the Limited API and CPython-optimised Cython, and had no answer. I then tried it with a simple caching example that uses ints, dicts and lists, and got a bit more than a 10% slowdown for the Limited API case. So, there are visible differences in the tricks that Cython pulls in the C-API, but in the end, these tricks have to add up to reach that difference, and are obviously highly code specific.

milestone.description:
Goals:
â€“ New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
â€“ Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3str`.
â€“ Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
â€“ Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Py_LIMITED_API / PEP 384
